head.hi: Tribute of one Philosopher to Another.

div.p:
The great Prussian Philosopher, Humboldt,
having been requested to pen a preface to the
Works of Arago, recently published in Paris, wrote
a charming personal sketch of the French scienti-
fic personage, with whom he had been in friendly
intercourse for forty years. The following is the
close of that sketch, after summing up the labors
and characteristic traits of the subject of his
notice:

“Such,” he continues, “is the picture, still in-
complete, notwithstanding the immenso wealth it
contains, of the labors of M. Arago. They have
elevated him to the rank of the most eminent men
of the nineteenth century. Wherever shall be
preserved respect for services rendered to science
or the sentiment of the dignity of man, and of the
freedom of thought; wherever shall be preserved
the love of public liberties, the name of Argo will
be honored. But it is not simply the authority of
a powerful intelligence which gave to M. Arago
the popularity he enjoyed. He was honored for
the unwavering zealous conscientiousness which
ever distinguished his conduct through life, and
which manifested itself in all its strength up to the
day of his death. To the very last moment he
made desperate efforts for the punctilious dis-
charge of duty. Nor must we forget the charms
of his conversation, the amenity of his manners,
and the benevolence of his character. Capable of
the, tenderest devotion, the natural goodness of his
heart ever checking the vivacity of an impulsive
temperament, M Arago enjoyed in the midst of
an affcetionate and talented family the peaceful
sweets of domestic life. All that the most tender
assiduity, the quick anticipation of his wants, and
the most ingenious and zealous affection to comfort
and console him or to assuage his pains during the
slow waning of his life, Arago experienced it in
the circle, unfortunately too restricted, of relatives
who were dear to him. Ho died surrounded by
his sons, his sister, M. de Matthieu, worthy of the
tender affection of such a brother, and by his niece,
Mme. Laugier whose devotion to him was of the
most touching character.

“Absent from M. Arago’s bed of suffering, I
have only been able to utter from a distance the
accents of my own lively grief. Even the certain-
ty of approaching affliction has not been to di-
minish its bitterness. As a final homage to him
who has just descended to the tomb. I will repeat
here a few lines which have already been publish-
ed elsewhere: ‘What characterized,’ I was saying,
‘this unique man, was not only the power of
genius which produces and fecundates, and that
rare lucidity of thought and expression whose
gift it is to develop new and complex ideas with
the ease, precision and elearness that would seem
to belong exclusively to subjects with which the
human intelligence has been long familiar, but it
was also the charming union of the strength and
elevation of an impassioned nature with an affec-
tionate gentleness of sentiment. I am proud to
think that by my tender devotion, and by the con-
stant admiration that I have expressed for him in
all my works, I have belonged to Arago for forty-
four years, and that my own will be sometimes
pronounced in association with his great name.
